text.p: Clarify Inc shares lost over half of their value Tuesday after the help-desk software developer said it expects little, if any, revenue growth in the second quarter over the first.

Shares of Clarify, based in San Jose, Calif., were down 9-5/8 at 7-1/8 on trading of 6.41 million shares, making the stock the second-most active in U.S. markets. Earlier, the shares traded as low as 6-1/2.
"They said their sales headcount wouldn't go up fast enough," said Ed Bierdeman, analyst at Dakin Securities in San Francisco.
After the market closed Monday, Clarify reported first-quarter net income of $1.95 million, or $0.09 a share, on revenue of $19.4 million -- about what Wall Street analysts expected.
But Clarify also said it expects "little, if any," revenue growth in the second quarter compared with the first, because the company cannot hire enough sales people.
The company did not provide any more details about its revenue forecast.

Clarify writes software that helps the customer-service department of companies keep track of customer complaints and requests. Clarify and other help-desk software companies have been seen their revenues double in recent quarters.

The dim revenue outlook from Clarify drove down other stocks in the help-desk niche. Remedy Corp fell 5-15/16 to 34-1/2. Vantive Corp fell 1-15/16 to 15-1/8. Scopus Technology Inc fell 4-7/8 to 23-1/4.
Bierdeman said Clarify and its rivals have a tough time showing Wall Street consistent and predictable revenue growth each quarter. Each sales contract usually takes months to complete, he said
PaineWebber Inc analyst John Faig downgraded the rating on Clarify to "neutral" from "buy," officials at the investment bank said.
Bierdeman said today's drop is a buying opportunity for the stock of the stronger companies, including Siebel Systems Inc and Vantive.
